message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest acute prostatitis, which is most commonly caused by Gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli. Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies are characteristic of E. coli on urine culture. The other options are not associated with acute prostatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute bacterial prostatitis, which is most commonly caused by gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli. Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies is the most likely result on urine culture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms the patient presents with suggest acute bacterial prostatitis. Among the given options, only Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies are commonly associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) and acute bacterial prostatitis. The other options correspond to other types of bacteria that are not commonly associated with UTIs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute bacterial prostatitis, and among the options, only Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies are associated with Enterobacteriaceae, which commonly cause acute bacterial prostatitis. The other options are associated with different types of bacteria and infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Urinary frequency and perineal pain suggest acute bacterial prostatitis. Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies indicate Escherichia coli, the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute bacterial prostatitis, which is most commonly caused by Gram-negative bacteria such as Escherichia coli. Gram-negative lactose-fermenting rods commonly cause urinary tract infections and prostatitis. The other options are not commonly associated with prostatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest acute bacterial prostatitis. Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies are typical findings of Escherichia coli, the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis. Gram-negative, oxidase-positive rods in green colonies are typical findings of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is not a common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis. Gram-negative, encapsulated rods in mucoid colonies are typical findings of Klebsiella pneumoniae, which is also not a common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis. Gram-negative, aerobic, intracellular diplococci are typical findings of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is more commonly associated with urethritis and epididymitis rather than prostatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest acute bacterial prostatitis. Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies most likely indicate Escherichia coli, the most common pathogen causing acute bacterial prostatitis. Option B, C, and D are more likely to indicate other bacterial infections such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella pneumonia, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest acute bacterial prostatitis, which is most commonly caused by Gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli. Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rods in pink colonies are indicative of E. coli. Option B describes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is not commonly associated with prostatitis. Option C describes Klebsiella pneumoniae, which can cause UTIs but is not commonly associated with prostatitis. Option D describes Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which can cause gonococcal prostatitis, but the patient is sexually active with his wife only and not at risk for gonorrhea.
